thread.title: Rescue after scaffold collapse at old Panmure Bridge, Auckland
thread.title_full: Rescue after scaffold collapse at old Panmure Bridge, Auckland

title: Rescue after scaffold collapse at old Panmure Bridge, Auckland
text:
Rescue after scaffold collapse at old Panmure Bridge, Auckland Last updated 12:29, February 21 2017 NZN VIDEO 
Dramatic rescue after scaffold collapse in Panmure, Auckland. 
A person was trapped against the Panmure Bridge in Auckland after scaffolding collapsed throwing six people into the water on Tuesday. 
Fire station officer Frank Walsh six people ended up in the water and one person was trapped on the under side of the bridge after the incident at 10am. 
That person was rescued by the fire service's high angle rescue team. They had used a turntable ladder appliance to reach the man, he said. 
A man was trapped by the fallen scaffolding, and was rescued by the fire service's high angle rescue team. 
The rescued man seemed unfazed by the drama. 
He drummed his hands against the bridge as he waited for help, then shook hands with his rescuers. 
Walsh said of the six people who ended up in the water, four were transported to hospital with minor to moderate injuries. NZN VIDEO 
Station Officer Frank Walsh speaks about rescue efforts after a scaffold collapse on the Old Panmure Bridge in Auckland. 
Witnesses told 1News the scaffolding collapse sounded "like a plane was landing". 
A local resident, who did not want to be named, said he heard a loud bang around the time the scaffolding collapsed. 
Scaffolding had been installed at the bridge for the past month, he said. CAT OWEN/FAIRFAX NZ 
A view of the collapsed scaffolding on Panmure Bridge. 
St John spokesman Mark Deoki said one patient in a moderate condition and two patients with minor injuries were taken to Middlemore Hospital. 
Another patient was being assessed at A&E. 
It was hard to determine exactly how the scaffolding collapsed, he said. 1 NEWS 
The collapse at the old Panmure Bridge left four people in the water. 
The bridge remained open to traffic. 
It is understood the bridge was undergoing paint and concrete repairs. 
WorkSafe spokesman Chris Baylis said the organisation had been notified and were making initial inquiries. CAT OWEN/FAIRFAX NZ 
Collapsed scaffolding in the lagoon beneath Panmure Bridge. CAT OWEN/FAIRFAX NZ
